item.title: Marvel’s Blade’s Rumored Morality System Could Explore the Character’s Darkest Storylines
item.description:
Marvel's Blade was announced at the 2023 Game Awards — a major win for any fans of uphill ice skating. The upcoming action game will follow the titular vampire slayer as he stalks his prey on the streets of Paris. The game will be developed by Bethesda subsidiary Arkane Lyon, which is known for its work on the Dishonored series and Deathloop .

Besides a reveal trailer and a tease for Blade's character design, details about this game are sparse. Most of what is known about the project is that it will be a single-player third-person experience with an original narrative. Though, based on a new rumor, Marvel's Blade 's plot could be taking quite a bit of inspiration from a lesser-known comic storyline.

Blade's Superpowers Could Come With Super Consequences

First shared in a recent video from the Double-Barrel Gaming YouTube channel, an anonymous source revealed that the developers behind Marvel's Blade are supposedly toying around with the idea of a morality system akin to that of the Infamous series. This could change by the time the game launches, or it could simply be nothing more than a rumor. That being said, integrating such a system into the game would make plenty of sense given the track records of both Arkane and the character Blade.

Morality Systems in Past Arkane Games

Arkane has long prioritized player choice in its games when it comes to both level design and narrative. This can especially be seen in the Dishonored series. Neither Corvo Attano nor Emily Kaldwin are presented as inherently evil protagonists, but players can choose to take them and the entire city of Dunwall down a destructive path thanks to Dishonored 's chaos system. Corvo and Emily are given vast arsenals of potentially deadly weapons and abilities, but killing is completely optional in the games.

Running through alleys, gunning down guards, and summoning a swarm of rats to eat them might be easier than sneaking through that environment, knocking the guards out, and hiding their unconscious bodies to avoid being discovered. However, going the lethal route will have noticeable consequences. The more chaos Corvo and Emily create during their time in the games, the darker an ending their stories will have.

Blade's Morality and the Impact of the Darkhold

Blade is typically depicted as a hero at best and an anti-hero at worst, but his morals have been corrupted on occasion. During a 1993 comic storyline, Blade found and read a passage from the Darkhold — an ancient spellbook filled to the brim with dark magic — that he believed would help him to destroy all monsters. Under the influence of the passage, the vampire hunter gained the ability to steal supernatural abilities from his opponents and became known as Switchblade.

Though these new powers allowed Switchblade to easily dispatch his foes, his continued reliance on them caused him to fall further and further under the malignant sway of the Darkhold. He became more monstrous in both body and mind. His bloodlust grew, and the feral Switchblade widened his scope beyond monsters as he began targeting anyone with supernatural abilities. Switchblade even killed the original Ghost Rider, Johnny Blaze, during his rampage. Switchblade was eventually defeated, but not before he had already left a trail of carnage in his wake.

Implementing a Morality System in Marvel's Blade

If Arkane is considering adding a morality system to its upcoming Marvel game, the Switchblade arc provides the perfect opportunity to do so. Arkane is known for giving its protagonists strange, mystical abilities that allow each player to navigate gameplay scenarios however they see fit. Adding the Darkhold to Marvel's Blade opens up avenues for Arkane to integrate similarly engaging powers into the game alongside Blade's traditional arsenal.

The Darkhold could then make way for branching pathways in the sandbox and the story. Whenever Blade takes down a vampire, the Darkhold presents him — and therefore the player — with a choice. He could take the creature's power, like how Colt could absorb enemy slabs in Deathloop . Doing so would grant Blade strength at the expense of his willpower and sanity. He could also choose to resist the Darkhold's thrall. This would maintain his composure while keeping Paris safe from a bloodthirsty Blade, but it would ensure that all future fights are more difficult. Arkane has proven that this sort of game design is right in their wheelhouse, and the nuance of potentially turning Blade evil in a playthrough would help to greatly differentiate Marvel's Blade from more straightforward superhero gaming narratives like those in the Marvel's Spider-Man series.

item.title: 7 Hidden Details From Mario & Luigi Brothership Overview
item.description:
Mario & Luigi is finally entering the Nintendo Switch library. It's been almost a decade since the previous new game in January 2016, Mario & Luigi Paper Jam. There have been remakes of Mario & Luigi Superstar and Bowser’s Inside Story between 2017 and 2018, though circumstances forced the developers, Alphadream, into bankruptcy. The series halted until another studio could perfectly take the series’ mantle, which wouldn’t be for some time until now.

Mario & Luigi Brothership is the first Mario & Luigi entry to join a home console rather than a handheld-based system. As its release date grows closer, Nintendo has unveiled more about the game through its overview video. They showcased more about the colorful world of Concordia, the expressive characters, and the gameplay format. Many details were unveiled through the video, including some smaller hints that weren’t fully explained.

7 Lushgreen Sea

Setting Sail

The Mario Brothers will sail across the Lushgreen Sea to discover different floating islands. The ship travels on certain routes that loop until the player picks a different route. This gives the brothers time to search for undiscovered islands with their telescope. There is an option to travel faster when rushing to another island.

When the brothers discover an island, it’s recorded on the map. The plumbers do need to explore each island on foot, though there’s a warp pipe used to fast-travel to different sections of the island.

6 Concordia

Lighting The World

Concordia is a world filled with inhabitants designed as simple plugs and outlets. This world’s source of connection is seen through their huge lightbulbs, which were snapped off by some ominous force. Connie and Snoutlet are the main supporters who will accompany the brothers as they bring light back to their broken unplugged world.

There are two currencies for the Mario brothers to collect: coins and light. Coins are much more common than light since they appear in the overworld and battle. Light only appears at more specified moments, making them more premium.

5 Characters

Returning Cast

Mario and Luigi's new journey will introduce some familiar characters. Starlow has returned, becoming more part of the series’ staple cast. She doesn’t seem to be with the Mario brothers, but with Princess Peach. She may work with the princess to assist the plumbers on their main quest.

Bowser Jr. is also involved, though something seems off with him. One scene showcases his chat with Kamek, mentioning “true allies.” It’s hinting at Jr’s issue with managing true bonds with others. This journey will test his character development as he learns how to make trustful, loyal allies like his father.

4 Gameplay

Brotherly Impact

The combat offers animated attacks with impactful strikes for the Mario brothers when confronting their foes. Offensively, the two brothers utilize teamwork much more often to deal greater damage, even during normal attacks rather than attack by themselves. Defensively, they utilize their usual jumps and hammers to dodge and counterattack. They can even use emergency guard to reduce incoming damage. When defeating regular enemies, they drop coins and presents for items.

The best convenience is when the brothers do platforming. Luigi halts at the ledge before jumping, easing the controls of the jumping plumbers rather than pressing both buttons in a quick sequence.

3 Antagonist

Wired Evil

Whatever is threatening Concordia is beyond Mario and Luigi to handle alone. The rivalry villains call themselves “Extension Corps,” since each villain spells out a part of their team name. They’re designed to be various electronic connectors like HDMI and aux jack connectors rather than simple plugs and outlets. The villainous leader even has a wire cutter in his appearance.

This conundrum forces the brothers to find some quick assistance, which leads them to Bowser. Despite his grudge against the Mario brothers, the Koopa King isn’t thrilled with sharing world domination with another villain. This motivation will drive him to start a war against the Extension army.

2 Battle Plugs

Connecting Abilities

Battle Plugs is the newest option for Mario and Luigi to utilize during battle. They are sorted into three categories: offensive, defensive, and support. Each category can enhance the Mario brothers’ abilities by widening the attack range or strengthening the defense. They can even use auto abilities similar to the gambits in Final Fantasy XII.

It’s shown that Mario and Luigi can equip only a certain number of plugs with their outlet storage. Within the trailer, they can equip at least two different plugs. Later, it’s revealed that the outlet capacity can increase up to four, giving the brothers four different enhancements. They must be cautious in battle as they’re not the only ones to use various abilities.

1 Luigi

Helpful Brother

Luigi is getting his chance to shine with his mind and independence through Luigi Logic. When an idea comes to mind, he can handle different actions to assist his brother. This allows him to deviate from his brother's path when a green aura shines. This occurs when he walks near certain interactions, giving Mario less burden to handle different tasks. This mechanic proves useful for the brothers’ main progression, especially during platforming.

His Logic also brings his strategic cunning into battle. After thinking with a familiar pose, he has an additional option that involves his creative solution. This can greatly sway the plumbers’ advantage during more intense boss battles.

item.title: 5 Scariest Mimic Enemies In Video Games
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Enemies in games can surprise players with mimics, turning seemingly harmless objects into deadly foes.
  • Mimics like Chest Mimic in Dark Souls or Grub Mimic in Hollow Knight can catch players off guard and lead to unexpected deaths.
  • Video game enemies like Teethalon in Shovel Knight or Typhon Mimic in Prey create tense and memorable encounters, adding depth to gameplay.

Most video games use an action-packed gameplay loop to keep players engaged, which mandates the need for a whole host of enemies that can push players to adjust to defeat anyone who stands in their way. This enemy variety can go a long way in making each battle a test where players figure out weaknesses and patterns, exploiting them to attain victory. It's a satisfying sensation to beat these foes into the ground, especially the stronger ones who give players a tough time.

However, there are times when games feature enemies that can catch players by surprise, pretending to be something else before rearing their ugly heads. It's a harrowing prospect, with these mimics turning into one of the most iconic and hated enemy types in gaming, and they excel at scaring players right when they get comfortable in a game.

5 Chest Mimic

An Organic Jumpscare That Makes Players Think Twice Before Opening Treasure Chests

Dark Souls is one of the greatest action RPGs of all time. The game wastes no time in showing players just how challenging it is, forcing them to follow a sound strategy and do everything in their power to beat down a boss that will decimate them time and time again. By the time players reach Anor Londo, they'll feel like they can handle most of the toughest enemies this title has to offer. However, this is when a mimic appears to take players by surprise.

Being chomped down on by a chest that supposedly houses treasure is one of the most jarring moments in a video game, and most players will be shocked to their core as all their precious health is wiped away in a flash. Unless the Chosen Undead is very powerful, this is a guaranteed death that will force players to stay on their toes from now on whenever they find a chest.

4 Teethalon

A Miniboss That Lures Players With A Treasure Chest

It's hard to believe that a game as charming as Shovel Knight can figure out a way to scare the player. After all, the retro graphics make it seem like this game won't lean into any horror tropes at all, which is why the fight against the Teethalon is such an effective way to scare the player. While exploring the Iron Whale, players stumble upon an inviting chest. As they move to open it, a horrible surprise lies in wait for them.

Instead of the treasure they coveted, players must take on a horrifying miniboss designed after an angler fish. The Teethalon is one of the most memorable encounters in the game, and anyone who fails to gather their bearings after encountering this boss will die in a flash. Thankfully, once players experience this unwanted surprise once, repeating this battle shouldn't be too much of a challenge.

3 Mad Piano

One Of The Most Iconic Scares In Retro Gaming History

Super Mario 64 is one of the greatest platformers of all time. It's amazing how Nintendo managed to help their favorite mascot transition seamlessly into 3D, with the gameplay loop feeling incredible to this day. Every level in the game is bursting with creativity, with the spooky nature of Big Boo's Haunt making for a nice change of pace from the chirpy levels of the game. For the most part, the scares in this game are more adorable than haunting, but that's before players enter a room with a piano.

Kids who played this game were traumatized when they approached this piano, only for it to burst into life horrifyingly, and for its gnashing teeth to shave off Mario's precious health. It's a moment that makes players panic and forces them to scramble back to a safe space, helping this stand out as one of the scariest enemies in a non-horror game that anyone can subject themselves to.

2 Typhon Mimic

The First Encounter With A Mimic Is Very Memorable

Prey is one of the most interesting immersive sims that fans can get their hands on. The desolate and lonely setting of Talos I makes for a terrifying setting, with players taking on the role of Morgan Yu who was seemingly trapped in a simulation before it breaks down and he manages to explore the halls of a desolate space station. It takes a while for the first enemy to rear its ugly head, but players will be sufficiently surprised when a random object morphs into a Typhon mimic that immediately jumps on their face.

It's a shocking moment that shows how players must stay on their toes and trust nothing in the environment. A single object out of place will cause players to fire in a panic, proving why Prey 's atmosphere is unmatched. Sure, these enemies become easier to manage as players make progress in this title, but the first few hours of Prey are uniquely tense because of the lingering threat of mimics scattered throughout the environment.

1 Grub Mimic

Lures Players In By Pretending To Be A Harmless Grub

Hollow Knight is a challenging game that takes no prisoners. Players must learn how to maneuver themselves and master the game's combat system if they don't want one of the title's many tough bosses to beat them into the ground. Hallownest is a dark and brooding world to explore, with some of its NPCs and the occasional trapped Grub being the only source of happiness in a landscape that is slowly wasting away.

However, not all the Grubs are worth saving. Sometimes, players will free one of these adorable critters, only to be taken aback by an enemy encounter as this cute insect turns into a horrifying one. If the player is unable to gather their bearings in time, then The Knight will fall and players will lose their precious progress in a flash, all due to a seemingly innocent little bug.

item.title: How to Get Vinh's Password in Life is Strange: Double Exposure (Without Using His Favor)
item.description:
Life is Strange: Double Exposure follows the other games in the series by asking you to solve some puzzles in order to get the information you need to solve the larger mystery at hand. One of these puzzles is trying to unlock Vinh's phone to see what he's hiding.

Max is tasked with finding out who murdered Safi in Life is Strange: Double Exposure , and Vinh is one of her prime suspects in Chapter 2. This is mainly because he's acting very suspiciously about his phone, and as a result, she needs to find the passcode to unlock it and discover his secret.

How to Unlock Vinh's Phone

​​​​​The first step on this mission is to speak with Vinh in the quad while you're in the living world, which will be available after you leave the bar at the start of the chapter. He has lost his phone, and he suspects that Diamond has stolen it. Speak to Diamond and eavesdrop on the Abraxas members nearby to discover that she likely didn't, and Vinh will tell you that you can find him in his office later.

You won't be able to find him in his office immediately, so complete the other two missions in the Fine Arts Building. Once you're done, you'll be able to find Vinh back in his office in the Living World. He has found his phone, but he's acting very secretive about it. He mentions that he can't remember his passcode because he's so hungover, but he knows it has something to do with the day a certain magician scientist died.

Max will remark that, thankfully, she knows another Vinh she can speak to, and this is your cue to transition to the Dead World using her dimension powers. Go back to Vinh's office in the Dead World, and you'll find him on the couch drinking a little too early in the day. While you speak with him, you can either use the favor he owes you to get his passcode, or you can find out which magician scientist he was talking about in the Living World.

He'll tell you the name of the magician, Jack Parsons. From here, you need to look for a book in the library which will tell you exactly the year he died. The book is on the shelves right next to the fireplace, on the left as you enter the library. If you aren't sure where to find the library, it's where you helped Gwen get the book from the locked bookcase.

Now that you have the code, return to the Living World and back to Vinh's office. He won't be there, but his phone will be lying on his desk. Use the passcode to open it and discover the secret he's hiding, and Max will be one step closer to unraveling the mystery of who killed Safi in Life is Strange: Double Exposure .

item.title: Elden Ring: 23 Easiest Bosses
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Elden Ring offers a variety of boss fights, with some being tougher challenges than others.
  • Some bosses have less of a skill wall, providing a needed boost to players before the end-game difficulty spike.
  • Players can expect memorable encounters with various bosses, ranging from tough challenges to more easily overcome battles.

Elden Ring was released to almost universal praise. With its mix of spectacle and tough challenges, it wowed audiences as often as it defeated them. Known as FromSoftware’s most accessible game, Elden Ring still pulls no punches when it comes to boss fights. Some of the toughest encounters in any of their games are found within The Lands Between.

Yet not all bosses are created equal, with many offering less of a challenge than others. In total, there are 238 boss fights in Elden Ring , many of which are boss versions of enemies that can be found roaming the world. Even among the unique or main quest bosses, not every encounter has a high skill wall to overcome, providing a much-needed boost to players before the end-game difficulty spike.

Updated October 20, 2024 by Andy Chapman : Shadow of the Erdtree released to widespread acclaim, with players old and new discovering the vast area that makes up the Land of Shadow. The DLC brought more challenges, from tough enemies hiding in every corner of the map to boss fights that test the limits of even the best players.

Elden Ring’s status as one of the best games ever made has been firmly established, with FromSoftware now one of the top game developers in the world. This article has been updated to include further entries to give a better overview of the easiest bosses in Elden Ring.

1 Scadutree Avatar

A Unique Triple Phase Boss

  • Location : Scadutree Base
  • Drops : 260,000 Runes, Remembrance of the Shadow Sunflower , Miquella's Great Rune
  • HP : 7,560, 13,608, 13,608

The Scadutree Avatar is certainly no push-over. With its three-phase battle and dangerous ranged attacks that inflict blood-loss buildup, this boss can deal heavy damage quickly. It’s possible to miss the Avatar entirely, as it is only accessible after players have drained the sunken area of the Shadow Keep.

Found at the base of the Scadutree, the monstrous sunflower is surprisingly quick. It can launch itself across the large arena at a moment’s notice, dealing high amounts of damage. While the Avatar is quick and dangerous, its HP is considerably less than other bosses in the DLC. This means a few well-timed attacks can put an end to the fight.

2 Morgott, The Omen King

Powerful and Fast, But Weak to Bleed

  • Location : Leyndell, Royal Capital
  • Drops : 120,000 Runes, Remembrance of the Omen King , Morgott's Great Rune .
  • HP : 10,399

This exciting boss encounter is found at the halfway point of the game and can be challenging for players due to the foe's fast movement and delayed attacks. Morgott guards the entrance to the Erdtree, and while it is certainly a tough fight, players will have already faced off against the character twice in the game.

Morgott, the Omen King is by far the hardest version of this boss, but by this point, players should have little trouble taking him down. His health bar is relatively small, his poise can be broken easily, and he is weak to lightning and bleed. The fight is epic in scale, and his attacks can seem relentless, but some well-timed hits will soon drain his health bar. While he may pose a challenge to some, most players will dispatch the Omen King after only a few attempts.

3 Fire Giant

Slow-Moving and Weak To Bleed

  • Location : Mountaintop Of The Giants
  • Drops : 180,000 Runes, Remembrance of the Fire Giant
  • HP : 42,363

This colossal boss fight may be epic in scale, but few players will struggle to overcome this memorable encounter. Elden Ring players will find this gargantuan enemy late in the game once they have traversed most of the map and found their way to the snowy region in the far north. Fire Giant guards the Forge of the Giants, which players need to reach to progress the main story.

When first encountered, this fight can prove tough due to the boss’ extreme size and equally large health pool. However, players will soon discover the Fire Giant can be taken down quicker than expected. One of his feet is a weak point, which allows players to reach the second phase quickly. The boss area also offers a lot of room and allows players to use Torrent for quicker mobility. In addition, bleed can be effective against this boss and will help to whittle away at its large amount of health.

4 Godfrey, First Elden Lord (Golden Shade)

A Fun Battle That Is Over Too Quickly

  • Location : Leyndell, Royal Capita
  • Drops : 80,000 Runes
  • HP : 7099

Leyndell, Royal Capital, is one of the most original and striking areas in Elden Ring , with tough challenges waiting around every corner. Eventually, players will come to a boss wall and meet the Golden Shade version of Godfrey, the First Elden Lord.

Godfrey, First Elden Lord is by no means a pushover, but compared to the real version encountered later in the game, he doesn’t quite live up to the name. By the time the player reaches this boss, they will have come up against tougher challenges and overcome them, so dealing with Godfrey shouldn't require too much work.

5 Mohg, The Omen

A Taster of the Real Thing

  • Location : Subterranean Shunning Grounds
  • Drops : 100,000 Runes
  • HP : 14,000

Much like Godfrey, this easier version of a tough later boss is underwhelming. Found below the royal capital, guarding a hidden wall that leads to the frenzied flame, Mohg, the Omen can dish out some heavy damage but offers little in the way of challenge.

With a limited move set and well-telegraphed attacks, most players will defeat Mohg relatively quickly. Also, like the Golden Shade Godfrey, players will be experienced enough in the game at this point to take on the fight with little to worry about.

6 Rykard, Lord Of Blasphemy

One Of The Best Spectacle Battles In Elden Ring

  • Location : Volcano Manor
  • Drops 130,000 Runes, Rykard's Great Rune , Remembrance of the Blasphemous
  • HP : 89,613

One of the most iconic fights in Elden Ring for the voice acting alone, Rykard is a terrifying gimmick fight that delivers in droves. What it lacks in difficulty, it makes up for in pure chaotic joy, reveling in its unabashed spectacle.

Found after completing the Volcano Manor legacy dungeon, the fight is more thematic than challenging, with the weapon needed for victory waiting at the opening of the boss room. Rykard is one of the central characters within the lore of the game, and it is a fight that shouldn’t be missed, even though the battle itself is lacking in terms of difficulty.

7 Margit, The Fell Omen

A Tough Challenge For New Players

  • Location : Stormveil Castle
  • Drops : 12,000, Talisman Pouch
  • HP : 4,174

The first major story boss that new players will encounter in the game, taking on Margit, the Fell Omen too early can be a true challenge. His attacks are fast and unrelenting, and finding an opening on a first attempt is tough. This boss fight is a test for players and a taste of what’s to come later.

A common mistake new players make in Elden Ring is taking on Margit too early. There’s all of Limgrave to explore before moving on to Stormveil Castle and plenty of opportunities to level up, find better gear, and take on easier boss fights. Elden Ring is a big game, and by taking the time to explore and level, players will discover that Margit isn’t the impossible challenge he first seemed.

8 Godrick The Grafted

A Fun Introduction To The Game

  • Location : Stormveil Castle
  • Drops : 20,000 Runes, Godrick's Great Rune , Remembrance of the Grafted
  • HP : 6,080

The Godrick boss fight is one of the highlights of the starting area in Elden Ring . This boss is found at the end of Stormveil Castle, the first major legacy dungeon in the game. The fight can be tough for those less experienced, but having already defeated the tougher Margit, the Fell Omen, players shouldn’t find Godrick to be too much of a challenge.

Although Godrick is one of the easier story bosses within the game, the fight offers a hugely enjoyable experience. Fast-paced, with a fun array of attacks, this battle has a ton of character.

9 Sir Gideon Ofnir, The All-Knowing

Dangerous Spells, But Weak to Attack

  • Location : Leyndell, Ashen Capital
  • Drops : 150,000 Runes, All-Knowing Helm , All-Knowing Armor , All-Knowing Gauntlets , All-Knowing Greaves , Scepter of the All-Knowing
  • HP : 6226

Players will first meet Sir Gideon when they reach the Roundtable Hold early in the game. This NPC acts as the leader of the Tarnished but is ruthless in his actions and holds many secrets to himself. Once players have progressed to the end stages of the game, Ofnir will reveal himself as a foe and stand in the way of them becoming Elden Lord.

This fight can be tough, as Sir Gideon Ofnir, The All-Knowing has access to many spells, both sorceries and incantations. The amount of spells he wields can depend on which shardbearers the player has defeated and which were reported to Ofnir earlier in the game. Although he can bombard players with a lot of magic, his health bar is small, so a few well-timed attacks will take him down quickly. Intelligence build characters can also use the Eternal Darkness sorcery, which will redirect almost all of his attacks.

10 Rennala, Queen Of The Full Moon

Powerful Magic That Fails Against Aggression

  • Location : Raya Lucaria Academy
  • Drops : 40,000 Runes, Remembrance of the Full Moon Queen , Great Rune of the Unborn .
  • HP : 3,493 in Phase 1; 4,097 in Phase 2

Rennala is another boss battle that is heavier on spectacle than difficulty. A central figure within the world of Elden Ring , the fight is required for the Age of Stars ending. It takes place at the end of The Academy of Raya Lucaria and has two distinct phases.

In the second phase, the fight truly begins. Rennala uses spells that can cause huge damage, but with a few well-timed attacks, her health can disappear quickly, ending the battle before it gets a chance to start.

11 Tree Sentinel

A Tough Challenge For New Players

  • Location : Limgrave
  • Drops : 3,200 Runes, Golden Halberd
  • HP : 2,889

Tree Sentinel is the first boss encounter in the game. As soon as the Tarnished leaves the tutorial dungeon, this golden armored rider is patrolling just below and is certainly a big challenge for new players. Taking on Tree Sentinel and defeating him then and there is possible but not recommended. It is much better to level up, find better equipment, and return later on.

Once players have gotten used to the game and improved their equipment, Tree Sentinel becomes a much easier encounter. His move set doesn’t change much throughout the fight, and most attacks are easily dodged.

12 Leonine Misbegotten

A Simple Battle in a Scenic Arena

  • Location : Castle Morne
  • Drops : 3,800 Runes, Grafted Blade Greatsword
  • HP : 2,198

One of the early notable battles in Elden Ring , Castle Morne isn’t one of the main story characters or even a lesser one. Versions of this boss also appear in the late game as common enemy encounters.

Found at the end of Castle Morne in the Weeping Peninsula, the boss has a move-set reminiscent of Slave Knight Gael in Dark Souls 3 . While it is a fast-paced fight, it has none of the impact of that battle. Nonetheless, the setting of the fight is stunning, and it is a good tester for later battles to come.

13 Ancient Dragon-Man

More Man Than Dragon

  • Location : Dragon's Pit
  • Drops : 130,00 Runes, Dragon-Hunter's Great Katana
  • HP : 21,859

Players will first encounter the Ancient Dragon-Man as an invader when approaching The Dragon’s Pit in the Shadow of the Erdtree DLC. Once the cave has been explored, players will find a deep hole. Dropping into the hole will reveal the fog wall to the real Ancient Dragon-Man.

This mini-boss guards the route to Jagged Peak and is a fun challenge for players. While Ancient Dragon-Man can deal significant damage, especially with his Dragon Communion Incantation attacks, he is ultimately no stronger than any other NPC found in the game. For achieving victory, players are rewarded with a powerful weapon, the Dragon-Hunter’s great Katana, which does additional damage against Dragons.

14 Tree Sentinels (Hinterlands)

Easy Bosses For Experienced Players

  • Location : Hinterlands
  • Drops : 120,000 Runes, Blessing of Marika
  • HP : 20,492-24,593

The Hinterlands is an area of Elden Ring’s DLC, Shadow of the Erdtree , in stark contrast to the rest of the Lands of Shadow. The area is lush with life and leads to one of the Hallowed Finger Ruins. It’s where players will find the beautiful Shaman Village, the home of Marika herself.

Before players can explore the area, they must pass two Tree Sentinels guarding the way. The Tree Sentinel, first encountered in Elden Ring , is a notoriously tough boss. At this stage of the game, however, two pose little threat. Players will easily dodge their attacks and quickly take them down. Each Sentinel can also be fought separately, making the encounter a simple battle easily won.

15 Jagged Peak Drake

A Familiar Encounter Players Will Breeze Through

  • Location : Jagged Peak
  • Drops : Dragon Heart, Dragonscale Flesh
  • HP : 39,377

Elden Ring’s massive DLC, Shadow of the Erdtree , has introduced several new Dragon encounters to the game. While some feel new, most are similar to the base game bosses. While this isn’t entirely a negative, as they are still fun battles against Dragons, many players may find the encounters too easy.

There are two Jagged Peak Drakes in the game. One is first encountered asleep when entering the Jagged Peak area. The second is found further on, battling another Dragon. Defeating this second Dragon will treat players with Igon's praise, furthering his questline. Players will likely have little issue with this field boss, as the other Dragon continues to attack the Drake. Players will easily find victory, as the moveset is virtually the same as previous lesser Dragons, barring its additional lightning attack.

16 Red Wolf Of Radagon

A Memorable Encounter Easily Overcome

  • Location : Raya Lucaria Academy
  • Drops : 14,000 Runes, Memory Stone
  • HP : 2,204

Midway through the Academy of Raya Lucaria can the Red Wolf of Radagon be found. This is another boss fight that is unique at this point in a playthrough, but other versions of the enemy can be found later on in the game, too.

Set within a lecture hall in the legacy dungeon, the battle is fast and fun, but it ends far too quickly. The fight is also reminiscent of the Great Grey Wolf Sif boss in the first Dark Souls game, which lends a perfect touch of nostalgia to the encounter for fans of soulslike experiences.

17 Chief Bloodfiend

An Easily Missed Mini-boss

  • Location : Rivermouth Cave
  • Drops : 80,000 Runes, Bloodfiend Hexer's Ashes
  • HP : 10,974

Located at the end of Rivermouth Cave, Chief Bloodfiend is a large and aggressive version of the commonly found Bloodfiend enemies. Bloodfiends are found throughout Shadow of the Erdtree and are worshipers of the outer god, The Formless Mother.

Chief Bloodfiend attacks mainly with wide swings, slams, and bloodflame magic. While its moves can deal reasonable damage, its attacks are well-telegraphed and players will have little trouble beating the boss within one or two tries. While the boss isn’t much of a challenge, the dank, blood-filled arena is a fitting backdrop for this fun side battle.

18 Commander O’Neil

Using Torrent Ensures A Swift Victory

  • Location : Swamp Of Aeonia
  • Drops : 12,000 Runes, Commander’s Standard Unalloyed Gold Needle
  • HP : 9,210

Deep within the infected swamps of Caelid, players will find Commander O'Neil . This boss fight is needed to progress the Millicent storyline. Unfortunately, the unique and unsettling backdrop of the encounter doesn’t carry over to the fight itself and is one of the more forgettable boss battles in the game.

Commander O’Neil can be easily defeated when using Torrent, giving players little in the way of challenge. A tougher version of this boss, Commander Niall, can be found in Castle Sol in the Mountain Tops of the Giants area, and defeating him is sure to remind players of how easy it is to beat Commander O'Neil.

19 Ancestor Spirit

A Powerful Atmospheric Battle

  • Location : Siofra River
  • Drops : 13,000 Runes, Ancestral Follower Ashes
  • HP : 4,393

Elden Ring is a game full of surprises, and one of the most stunning is revealed when using the lift to get down to the Siofra River area. After lighting all the pillars in this underground level, players are treated to a stunning boss fight.

The Ancestor Spirit boss is an easy fight to overcome, offering barely a challenge even to new players, but its beautiful design and eerie atmosphere make it a must for any playthrough of the game. The Regal Ancestor Spirit found in Nokron, Eternal City, is an equally memorable boss fight that only provides a little more challenge.

20 Mimic Tear

Fighting Yourself Has Never Been Easier

  • Location : Nokron, Eternal City
  • Drops : 10,000 Runes
  • HP : 19,536

Found after entering Nokron, Eternal City, the Mimic Tear is one of the easiest unique fights in the game. Fighting the player's own character should be more of a challenge, but unfortunately, the mimic rarely compares to the real thing.

Encountered partway through the level, the Mimic Tear is almost a forgettable fight but acts as a prelude to finding one of the best items in the entire game, the Mimic Tear Spirit Ashes. Ironically, the Mimic Tear Spirit Summon is one of the strongest in all of Elden Ring , often turning even difficult endgame bosses into easy wins.
